articles.headline: Volkswagen Reaches Deal in U.S. Over Emissions Scandal
articles.snippet: Owners of hundreds of thousands of diesel vehicles in the United States will be eligible to have their vehicles bought back or fixed.
articles.abstract: Owners of hundreds of thousands of diesel vehicles in the United States will be eligible to have their vehicles bought back or fixed.
articles.lead_paragraph: Volkswagen agreed on Thursday to fix or buy back nearly 500,000 diesel cars in the United States that are equipped with illegal emissions software.

articles.headline: Wall St. Regulators Propose Stricter Pay Rules for Bankers
articles.snippet: The new rules would make executives wait at least four years to receive portions of their bonuses and force banks to find ways to claw back bonuses.
articles.abstract: The new rules would make executives wait at least four years to receive portions of their bonuses and force banks to find ways to claw back bonuses.
articles.lead_paragraph: Regulators released long-awaited rules on Thursday morning that aim to restrict how big financial institutions can pay their top executives.

articles.headline: With Uncertainty at Top of Ticket, Republicans Back Off in Some States
articles.snippet: The Republican National Committee’s decision to hold off on spending in some contested states shows how a divisive presidential race is threatening the entire ticket.
articles.abstract: The Republican National Committee’s decision to hold off on spending in some contested states shows how a divisive presidential race is threatening the entire ticket.
articles.lead_paragraph: HOLLYWOOD, Fla. — The Republican National Committee is scaling back its financial commitments to some of the most hotly contested states because of flagging fund-raising, the most concrete evidence yet of how the party’s divisive and protracted presidential race is threatening the party’s entire ticket in November.

articles.headline: Apple Services Shut Down in China in Startling About-Face
articles.snippet: The iBooks Store and iTunes Movies were closed six months after they began in China, which had been more welcoming of Apple than other tech companies.
articles.abstract: The iBooks Store and iTunes Movies were closed six months after they began in China, which had been more welcoming of Apple than other tech companies.
articles.lead_paragraph: For years, there has been a limit to the success of American technology companies in China. Capture too much market share or wield too much influence, and Beijing will push back.
articles.byline: By Paul Mozur and Jane Perlez

articles.headline: Menstruation Joins the Economic Conversation
articles.snippet: Businesses, lawmakers and advertisers, prodded in large part by calls for gender equality, have sought ways to make menstrual cycles less agonizing.
articles.abstract: Businesses, lawmakers and advertisers, prodded in large part by calls for gender equality, have sought ways to make menstrual cycles less agonizing.
articles.lead_paragraph: Late-night pharmacy runs. Bulky pads. Periods have simply long been an uncomfortable experience.

articles.headline: Uber Settles Cases With Concessions, but Drivers Stay Freelancers
articles.snippet: A settlement will let Uber continue to categorize drivers in California and Massachusetts as independent contractors.
articles.abstract: A settlement will let Uber continue to categorize drivers in California and Massachusetts as independent contractors.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Uber has long been embroiled in a debate over the status of its drivers: Should they be independent contractors or full-time employees?
articles.byline: By Mike Isaac and Noam Scheiber

articles.headline: Donald Trump’s More Accepting Views on Gay Issues Set Him Apart in G.O.P.
articles.snippet: His ease with gay people does not seem to be the result of deep soul searching, but, rather, the product of the Manhattan social and political world he has inhabited the past five decades.
articles.abstract: His ease with gay people does not seem to be the result of deep soul searching, but, rather, the product of the Manhattan social and political world he has inhabited the past five decades.
articles.lead_paragraph: Elton John and his longtime boyfriend, David Furnish, entered a civil partnership on Dec. 21, 2005, in England under a law the country had just enacted granting recognition to same-sex couples. The congratulations poured in as the two men appeared at a joyous ceremony at Windsor Guildhall, amid a crush of paparazzi. Donald J. Trump, who had known the couple for years, took to his blog to express his excitement.

articles.headline: In a Big Hole for a Detroit House, but Happy
articles.snippet: Amy Haimerl and Karl Kaebnick have gone into debt for a house valued at $100,000 less than they’ve spent. But they love it.
articles.abstract: Amy Haimerl and Karl Kaebnick have gone into debt for a house valued at $100,000 less than they’ve spent. But they love it.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT — Many residents of high-cost areas entertain the dream, at least occasionally: Give up the rent or mortgage grind, liquidate assets and start over someplace cheaper, perhaps one that could use a few spirited new residents.

articles.headline: VW, Setting Aside $18 Billion for Diesel Scandal Costs, Reports Record Loss
articles.snippet: The automaker said it had lost $6.2 billion in 2015, and the German government on Friday ordered a recall of 630,000 diesel vehicles from VW and other automakers.
articles.abstract: The automaker said it had lost $6.2 billion in 2015, and the German government on Friday ordered a recall of 630,000 diesel vehicles from VW and other automakers.
articles.lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — Volkswagen reported a record loss for 2015 on Friday as it set aside more than $18 billion to cover the cost of fines, legal claims and recalls in the United States and other countries related to diesel emissions cheating.

articles.headline: Virginia Governor Restores Voting Rights to Felons
articles.snippet: Gov. Terry McAuliffe used his executive power to allow more than 200,000 convicted felons to vote, circumventing the Republican-run legislature.
articles.abstract: Gov. Terry McAuliffe used his executive power to allow more than 200,000 convicted felons to vote, circumventing the Republican-run legislature.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Gov. Terry McAuliffe of Virginia used his executive power on Friday to restore voting rights to more than 200,000 convicted felons, circumventing the Republican-run legislature. The action effectively overturns a Civil War-era provision in the state’s Constitution aimed, he said, at disenfranchising African-Americans.
articles.byline: By Sheryl Gay Stolberg and Erik Eckholm

articles.headline: Mushroom Suits, Biodegradable Urns and Death’s Green Frontier
articles.snippet: A growing number of products rely on sleek design and online publicity to get people comfortable with an environmentally friendly death.
articles.abstract: A growing number of products rely on sleek design and online publicity to get people comfortable with an environmentally friendly death.
articles.lead_paragraph: Jae Rhim Lee wants you to be less squeamish about death, and she thinks a suit lined with flesh-eating mushrooms might do the trick.
